name: SNAC
body:
### Sensor Networks for Autonomous Cars SNAC is a system designed for use in the next generation of autonomous cars. Currently, it is capable of the following: * Counting the number of cars in opposing traffic * Speed estimation of cars in opposing traffic * Logging GPS and any OBD data Utilizing this information, it is capable of traffic estimation, primarily using monocular vision. When combined with a wireless communication network, in theory, it will be able to generate crowdsourced traffic information. Some features to be implemented in the future: * Mapping capability to geographically store data * Robust detection of various traffic signs (stop signs, yield signs, speed limit signs, etc.) * Detection of obstacles (cars stopped on the road, accidents, major potholes, etc.) ### The system "Picture of in car assembly" rerer Sensors: * 1 x [Omnivision OV10635 USB 3.0 Camera](https://www.leopardimaging.com/LI-USB30-OV10635.html) * 1 x [Garmin GPS18-5Hz](https://buy.garmin.com/en-US/US/oem/sensors-and-boards/gps-18x-oem/prod27594.html) * 1 x [On-board Diagnostics sensor](https://www.amazon.com/Version-Bluetooth-Multi-Language-12Kinds-Android/dp/B00N2K6M2A)
100 200 300
400 500 600
### Methods ![System workflow](http://i.imgur.com/bEm7A89.jpg) opencv optical flow (farneback) neural network - trained yolo (reference paper and site) architecture on VOC car images. this gives bounding boxes bounding box metadata is enough to be able to count how many opposing cars pass by. with the culmination of optical flow and bounding box data, a logistic classifier predicts the speed of the vehicle. finally greenshield's eq, which requires the count and speeds, outputs a traffic estimate. ### Authors Ajay Srivastava and Pavan Purohit {as1877, pp428}@rutgers.edu
